boardgame.name: Minions
boardgame.description:
32 cards, four of each family (color) that make it possible to play two games:

Action Game:

The object of this game is to get rid of all your cards as soon as possible. Each player gets 5 cards and the rest go in a pile face-down with 1 card turn up next to it. In a player turn he must play a card with the same colour, number or symbol as the face-up next to the draw pile. When a card with a symbol it's played, the action related to that symbol must be performed. Then the next player goes.
When no card can be played, the player must take the top card from the face-down pile. If that card matches it can be played, if not the turn moves for the next player.
You win if get rid of all your cards.

Family Game:

The object of the game is to get the most families of minions you can (4 of each colour makes a family). One player ask for a type of card to any other player. If he can form a family he displays it in front of it and can continue until one player can group all the families he has in his hand at any given moment.
If a player asks a card and the other player does not have it that player's turn ends.

boardgame.name: Glass Road: Harlequin
Die Glasstraße: Harlekin
글래스 로드 : 어릿광대
boardgame.description:
This new specialist card expands the solo game variant.

When you choose Harlekin for a building period, do not shuffle it with the other cards. Put it at the bottom of the shuffled stack instead. Harlekin will always be one of the last two cards from which you can choose one to play for both actions.

His first ability clears all remaining buildings in a row on the central board.

His second ability gives you 3 of a certain resource, determined by rolling a die.

This expansion, originally available as a promotional item in Spielbox 2015/7, appears in the Glass Road base game starting with the 2021 editions.

boardgame.name: Do My Bidding
boardgame.description:
Put down your weapons! You fought your battles, now hire heroes for the hard work. Players bid to complete quests and earn rewards.

Each player begins with gold that they use to secretly bid for Heroes to complete their quests. The player with the highest bid wins the Hero's service. Their quest and hero is set aside until the required number of days (turns) pass. The Hero then returns with gold. Journey tokens add twists that may help or hurt players. Play continues around the table with new quests and new heroes. After 10 turns any heroes still out questing come home and all players count their gold to see who is richest!

boardgame.name: Mystery-Dish Diner
boardgame.description:
From the box:

"A fast-paced guessing game of delicious deduction.

Take turns playing customer and server. As the customer, make three food selections. Place your order by displaying the menu clue cards. Flip the timer! The server rushes to fill the order by using the clues. Ring the bell when the order is correct!

The more food items you serve correctly, the more money you earn! Switch roles and play again!"

This game for young children features cardboard food items, matching clue cards, and a screen to allow the customer to secretly choose three food items. The server can see only the clues (one for each item, describing color, shape, or temperature) and must figure out the customer's order using logic and process of elimination.

boardgame.name: Battles: Win or Lose
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Battles: Win or Lose is a well-developed card game incorporating elements of standard table-top role-playing games. Although dice are used, generally speaking the play centers on cards. The play surface is divided into four Zones for each player, called Portal, Umbra, Stage, and Mausoleum. In addition, there is a Rank Slot. Cards are played into Zones with different combinations of abilities being available in each. Many cards represent characters, when active they are called Mobs. Play proceeds in Turns comprising Rounds.

The game typically is distributed as a ZIP archive, with the rule book, some print-and-play components, and a layout document.

boardgame.name: Super Smash Quest Brawl
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The setting and several notable non-player characters of Super Smash Quest Brawl are derived from the Nintendo video game. The game system itself is an adaptation of the Exalted D10 flavor of White Wolf's Storytelling System. The game was designed for play over IRC (Internet Relay Chat), though it is not dependent upon that venue (however, most of the game materials, such as the character record sheet, are presented as text-only). Character creation supports a wide variety of characters though the focus is heavily on combat moves and abilities.

The game includes a "Smash Dex" with several entries derived from the video game (e.g., a small Bestiary).

boardgame.description:
1% is a deckbuilding game where not only are you building your deck collecting point and/or useful card while also trying to take over sites that give you powerful abilities. Collecting three of these sites instantly wins the game so players must be aware, battle opponent's crew, and interact more than your usual deckbuilder.
A drafting mechanic while setting up allows you to customize your gang members prior to play so you feel like you have actually customized your crew from actual strategy and choice.

boardgame.name: Kalarsys: Core Rulebook (HTML Versions)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Kalarsys: Core Rulebook was made freely available in three versions (0.6.2, 0.7.0, 0.7.1); the differences are minor refinements, though the organization of the 0.7.1 version is improved. Character creation begins with biographical and background information. Characters have "Stats" (Attributes), grouped into Body, Mind, and Skill categories. Body is split into Strength and Vitality; Mind into Intelligence and Willpower; and Skill into Concentration and Dexterity. Points are distributed into these Stats from pools associated with the groups. Derived Stats are then calculated, and then a list of Abilities (special capabilities) are identified.

A version 0.7.2 apparently was developed but not released.

boardgame.name: Kalarsys Accessories
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Two versions of the basic character sheet for Kalarsys were provided. One, the most basic, was offered in a GIF graphic format for full-page printing. The second was offered as a more-traditional PDF file; this version featured more options for the evolving system.

A non-player character generator was provided for Kalarsys. This software would randomly generate statistics. It was released as "Version 3" for Unix or DOS; "Version 4" for DOS; and "Version 5" for DOS, with source code. A "Version 6" was developed but (apparently) not released. The generator offered several methods of customization though, reportedly, most did not function as anticipated.

A Kalarsys Dice Roller, or KDice, program was released as a "Version 0.1" for DOS and a "Version 2" for DOS, with source code. For some time the dice roller was also available via a web browser. It was functional, but basic.

The 0.7.5 release in PDF has several appendices which add substantive clarification and details to the rules. The PDF version is also available in MOBI format as well as being available for free online viewing in HTML.

boardgame.name: The Next Penelope
boardgame.description:
Set in a futuristic Odyssey, "The Next Penelope" is a fast paced action racing game with loud colors, an original story and a challenging risk-reward system. Weapons can be mixed and used at any time, but all these abilities cost vital energy, so the player is very powerful and close to death at the same time!

As Penelope is looking for Ulysses through the galaxy, the player is free to explore the planets in any order. Each world features unique situations, races, even bosses, and new permanent abilities to enhance the Penelope's spaceship.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: The Game With No Name
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The core rule book presents all system rules needed for play. The book is not organized particularly well, however, and there is little-to-no support for unexperienced players. The central mechanic involves a single D6 roll, attempting to "roll under" a target number which, typically, is a Skill rating. A roll of 1 is always success--and possibly good success, at that. A roll of 6 indicates "something really bad may have just occurred". Both 1 and 6 rolls require a second roll to "confirm", which occurs on a second roll of 1 or 6.

boardgame.name: Tales of Arcana Roleplaying Card Game
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Tales of Arcana provides a simple structure for a collaborative storytelling game. The Story Master (SM) leads the narrative while the players use cards representing their characters to affect the story. The text and images on the cards serve to guide storytelling. The players can’t reuse cards until they play most of their hands, so they have to be creative.

The ideal number of players is three, though the Story Master can decide to include more. Each game session takes 1 to 3 hours and requires at least 1 six-sided die (d6), which you can find in many board games...

Each player creates a character with a hand of six character cards. This represents the character’s narrative DNA. Cards can be drawn at random or drafted. A character hand must include 1 Race card, 1 Class card, 1 Trait card, 1 Armament card, and 2 Ability cards. You can use these cards to recreate classic RPG classes or beloved fictional characters. During play, you might pretend that you are that character, adopting mannerisms or accents, or you might simply describe his or her actions.

Footy Feud! is an Australian football themed-card game.

Players are dealt numeric cards, and choose the highest value for scoring.
The objective is to have the highest score at the end of the game (played over 4 quarters).

4 cards in the deck allow stealing or score multiplication.

No; Footy Feud! has tested very well with people of all ages who have no interest in Australian football.
If you are familiar with the Australian football scoring method it may make the game initially easier to grasp.

boardgame.description:
One dark and gloomy night, the kingdom of Alexandria is attacked by an evil sorcerer and his army of darkness! Despite their best efforts to protect their king and their princess, the royal guard falls, one-by-one, to the forces of evil. Castle In The Darkness is a fun and challenging shout out to the early days of video games! It's an action exploration platformer with some RPG elements, much like games from the Castlevania or Metroid series. It's super fast-paced, challenging, and full of so many secrets that hey all might never be found!

boardgame.name: Draftica
boardgame.description:
In Draftica, each player is a Celtic chieftain assembling a tribe of 18 cards. Combinations of cards score points, and the player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

Players do this by collecting (or "drafting") both common cards in the colours red, green, blue and yellow, and rarer special cards that can provide a substantial reward for specialising in certain types of card.

Unlike some other drafting games, there is no lengthy playout phase to determine a winner - the game takes place entirely in the drafting phase itself, with many opportunities to outwit and outmanoeuvre your rivals. May the best drafter win!

boardgame.name: La banda dei pinguini
Manchots Barjots
Pingvasion
Szeregowy Pingwin
Zany Penguins
爆走企鵝
자니 펭귄
boardgame.description:
In Zany Penguins, you want to make sure that your tribe of penguins is the one that takes control of the Earth, so do what you can to take charge of regions such as the desert, jungle, and the North Pole.

In game terms, each region has a set of cards numbered 1-9. To set up, shuffle the deck, then deal each player a personal deck of 18 cards. Each player starts with two cards in hand.

On a turn, you draw two cards, pass one card each to your left- and right-hand neighbors, take the cards passed to you, then simultaneously play and reveal one card in front of you on the table. If you play a 1, on your next turn you play and reveal two cards instead of one; if you play a 2, it blows up all 6-9 cards played that same turn; and if you play a 3, on the subsequent turn everyone else plays before you do.

After eight turns, for each card color on the table in front of you in which you have the highest sum of all players, you score the sum of all cards of this color in your hand. For each color in which you don't have the highest sum, you score the single lowest card of this color in your hand. Players tally their scores, and whoever has the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Kentucky Route Zero: Act III
Kentucky Route Zero: Episode 3
boardgame.description:
The Act opens with Conway dreaming of a previous conversation he had with Lysette. The two recall a tragic event involving Charlie, Lysette's son, and Lysette informs Conway of a new delivery to be made, which will be the last delivery of Lysette's antique shop. Conway awakens from the Neurypnol TM-induced sleep at Doctor Truman's house to find his injured leg replaced with a strange skeletal limb giving off a yellow glow. After returning to the Museum of Dwellings to find it closed for the night, Conway, Shannon and Ezra resume their search for Lula Chamberlain in Conway's truck. The three are quickly stopped again, however, after the truck's engine breaks down. While Shannon calls for a tow truck, two musicians, Johnny and Junebug, pass the group on a motorcycle with a sidecar, and after some discussion decide to help the group get the truck moving again in exchange for following them to the Lower Depths bar to watch their performance. The group agrees, traveling to the Lower Depths and talking with Harry, the bartender, who gives directions back to Route Zero. After their performance, Johnny and Junebug decide to accompany Conway, Shannon and Ezra on their travels.

Source: Wikipedia, "Kentucky Route Zero", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Just Four Kicks
boardgame.description:
From the publisher's website:
Have you ever found yourself...

Not knowing what you're doing at the gym
Being too drunk at a wedding
Farting in yoga class

Just Four Kicks is a hilarious party game where anything can happen through creativity, quick thinking, and general debauchery. Watch your friends try to act out “being too drunk at a wedding” or use someone else’s body to depict “farting in yoga class.” Bring it to your next game night and it'll be guaranteed to bring your friends together through countless laughs and just a touch of embarrassment.

from the back of the box:
Do you like fun? Do you enjoy laughing? Are you interested in having an all around good time? If you answered yes to any of these questions (hopefully all) grab a copy of Just Four Kicks and prepare to have the time of your life. Inside jokes included in the box.

Now I'm sure you're thinking, wow, this game sounds amazing, how is it played? Start by finding at least three friends (or strangers) and splitting into two equal teams. Just Four Kicks has four rounds of play that will get progressively more intense and hilarious, so choose your teammates wisely. Each player has 30 seconds to get their team to guess as many cards as possible by describing the topic, doing charades, or using someone else's body as a puppet. The team that guesses the most cards wins!

boardgame.name: Eon Altar - Episode 1: The Battle for Tarnum
Eon Altar: Episode 1 – The Battle for Tarnum
boardgame.description:
An ancient, malevolent force stirs within the depths of the Eon Altar, and it’s up to YOU to stop it! Eon Altar combines nail-biting action and turn-based tactical combat with an epic story of friendship, destiny and betrayal.

So far so good, right? But wait, there's more!

In Eon Altar, we’ve captured the experience of a role-playing tabletop game and blended it into a video game. How did we pull that off? Well, the magic is in your own pocket.

In Eon Altar, each player uses their smartphone as a private screen to see their motivations, thoughts and innermost secrets. Your mobile device also offers you lines of dialogues to read out loud—hopefully in your own eccentric performance you've developed for your character.

Your actions. Your game. Your way. You play your character the way you want it. Succeed together, or die alone.

Eon Altar is a groundbreaking local co-op RPG for 1-4 players.

FEATURES:

Each player controls the action on the monitor from their smartphone or tablet with context sensitive information. Not only do you control and upgrade your character using the controller App, you receive secret thoughts, quests and dialogue during the campaign mode.
Choose whether to share personal information with your friends, or use it against them as you make impactful choices and forge your own destiny.
Play one of five different characters, each with their own back story, decisions, quests and powers. Explore the dungeons below Tarnum in real time and fight in team-turn-based-tactical combat.
Take your turns in any order for maximum tactical ownage, or even simultaneously for super speedy fights. Upgrade and manage your character without interrupting other players.
NPCs are fully voice activated, but you voice your own character! Make decisions about how much you want to give away to the rest of your party, and how much you keep close to your chest.
Explore a deep, compelling and original sword-and-sorcery fantasy world in real time, and fight in team-turn-based tactical combat.
Defeat legendary enemies in exciting tactical turn-based combat in the Combat Arena as you are challenged by endless waves of enemies.


Source: The Game Website.

- Play with your friends via full cross-platform multiplayer! Bring your ship into your friends' worlds, or have them join yours.
- Play as much or as little as you like. The game saves your progress on the spot -- no need to save manually.
- Play it how you want: relax and immerse yourself doing trading and questing, or venture forth into pirate-infested lands for some high-adrenaline naval combat.
- Unlock new ships, find upgrades, recruit allies, fund new towns, build coastal defenses, even bribe pirates to join your cause!
- Extensive talent tree with role-specific specializations.
- Customize your ship to make it look how you want. Pink hull with black sails? Sure, why not!
- Procedural itemization system where higher difficulty automatically means better rewards.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Thrones
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

Thrones is a two-player 9x9 board game where each players set their tiles and pieces secretly, screened from their opponent's view, until the screen is removed, the middle fifth row is set, and the battle's combat begins.

Gameplay:
Each player controls an army of 13 and a homeland of 36 tiles, including 1 Fortress.

A screen separates the players as they set their sides of the battlefield in secret.

Before the screen is removed, both players choose positions for the tiles in a middle row between their two sides.

Once the screen is removed, the middle row tiles positions are resolved, and the remaining empty space is occupied by a neutral Fortress.

The game begins! Tiles affect their piece’s ability to move, attack, and defend itself- sometimes to their benefit, sometimes not. Players must battle their opponent’s army while preserving their own, but will lose if they lose their Throne piece.

A player instantly defeats their opponent by moving their Throne piece into their enemy's Fortress- no matter what pieces either player controls.

boardgame.name: Action Max
boardgame.description:
The Action Max had a very limited release outside the US and only one PAL game is suspected to have been made. The Action Max system requires the player to also have a VCR, as the console does not have a way to play the requisite VHS tapes itself. Using light guns, players shoot at the screen. The gaming is strictly point-based and dependent on shot accuracy. Players can not truly lose or win a game. The system's post-launch appeal was limited by this and by the fact that the only real genre on the system are light gun games that play exactly the same way every time, leading to its quick market decline.

Source: Wikipedia, "Action Max", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

User Summary

NUON was a failed attempt by Toshiba, Motorola, Samsung, and Raite Optoelectronics to add gaming, internet, and enhanced navigation to certain DVD players. NUON technology was developed by VM Labs Inc. as an attempt to turn passive digital video into an interactive experience. A powerful 128-bit processor to embed in DVD players. The NUON had the power to decode audio and video while providing and enhanced UI and trick-play modes. More importantly, it provided a platform for 3D digital interactive content straight from a DVD player.

The Samsung Extiva DVD-N2000 was the first DVD player released to take advantage of Nuon technology.

It came packaged with a wired controller which plugged into one of two ports on the front of the unit. It also came with a demo disk and a full game - Ballistic.

1 “Fastest treasure collector” bonus tile
The first player to collect at least 1 gold nugget or 1 crystal in every adventure receives this bonus tile.
Value: 2 victory points.

The first player to collect at least 4 gold nuggets or crystals in any one adventure receives this bonus tile.
Value: 3 victory points.

The first player to use routes to connect all the adventurers with temples that match their color receives this bonus tile.
Value: 3 victory points.

4 “Fastest runner” bonus tile
The first player to move all their adventurers at least once receives this bonus tile.
Value: 2 victory points.

boardgame.name: Anno Domini: Reisen und Verkehr
boardgame.description:
Each Anno Domini game consists of 336 cards, with a description of a historical event on one side of the card and the year (and sometimes specific date) in which it happened on the other. Anno Domini: Reisen und Verkehr contains historical events related to voyages of famous people, transport, traffic motorization, etc. Like all Anno Domini sets, this game can be played as a standalone or mixed with some or even all editions.

In Anno Domini: Reisen und Verkehr, each player receives nine cards (or fewer, if you want the game to be shorter) and may look only at the descriptions. In turn, players place a card on the table, trying to place their card in chronological order to those already present. Instead of adding a card, a player may claim that the order in which the cards have been placed is incorrect. In this case all cards are turned over and the correct years revealed.

If the order is correct, then the doubting player receives two cards and skips a turn. If the order is incorrect, then the previous player – who accepted the order as correct or made it incorrect through her own placement – receives three cards. The first player with no cards remaining in hand wins.

boardgame.name: Rebellious Archetypes Volume VII
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Be a Rebel with a Cause!

Not every evil lurks in deep, dark dungeons far away from innocent townsfolk, waiting patiently for adventurers to kick down their doors and start fighting. Some monsters don't just prey on society from without, but have burrowed and wormed their way into the very heart of the civilized world, and twist and corrupt the very laws that are supposed to protect the innocent, using them to oppress and exploit them, instead. These evils are no less a threat than the ones that most adventurers face, but many PCs are ill-equipped to deal with them. This is a job for rebels.

This book presents five new rebellious archetypes for five different classes. Included are the feral rebel, a hunter archetype whose animal companion can change shape, and who specializes in infiltration and sabotage, the bloody sickle, a medium spirit devoted to revolution and casting down the aristocracy, the guerilla agent, a ranger archetype that specializes in hit-and-run tactics and develops a taste for fighting certain organizations, the partisan, a skald archetype that focuses in winning over the hearts and minds of the public, by any means necessary, and finally the divine liberator, a warpriest archetype devoted to freedom in all its forms, who tears down symbols of oppression, lights the way of freedom, and inspires her allies to great deeds.

Whether you're about to embark on a politically-themed campaign (such as the official Paizo adventure path focusing on revolution), or you just want a selection of exciting new abilities for passionate and freedom-loving PCs, this book has lots of tantalizing options to offer. Even GMs can get in on the fun, as several of the archetypes here are perfect for rebellious villains as well, and can make for exciting and memorable encounters.

boardgame.name: Trials of the Magi
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Trials of the Magi is a tabletop role-playing game centered around the idea that arcane spell casters known as Magi exist within our world and have kept their existence hidden for thousands of years. Those with the potential to learn magic are scouted out and must prove themselves worthy by undergoing a specialized exam.

Inside each session of this narrative card game a group of Candidates attempt to overcome the surreal and magical challenges put before them by the Arcane Scout. Where each success bringing them one step closer to becoming fledgling Magi.

Who is this game for:

While any group of players can pick up and play the game, Trials of the Magi was developed as a tool to introduce new players to the hobby of role-playing games. This goal is achieved through the game’s quick to learn, tactile mechanics and the ease of roleplaying within the game's fiction.
In contrast with most role-playing games, the characters that the players control in Trials of the Magi are direct representations of themselves known as Personas. These imagined characters look, act and talk just as the player would, making it easy for some one new to the hobby to step into their first game.

How the game is played:

The Candidates construct their personas by choosing 3 cards from the four possible Tarot suits of Swords, Wands, Cups or Coins. Then by answering a suit specific question they determine the source of the cards power, and write it on the card. This written word shapes the narrative capabilities of each card, as it represents what form of magic the Persona has access to within the mental landscapes of the trials.
Each Tarot suit represents a type of playstyle, and by picking a combination of 3 cards, you tailor your gameplaying interactions effectively create your own custom “character class”.

This hand of cards comprises the entirety of each player’s Persona, and gameplay revolves around each player’s ability to effectively manage how their cards cycle between the three positions of, in their hand, on the table, or discarded. This is crucial because if all of the players are forced to discard all of their cards, they fail the trial.

boardgame.name: Team Yankee
boardgame.description:
Team Yankee is a tabletop miniatures wargame that is set in a fictional World War III in 1985 based on the novel of the same name by Harold Coyle.

The game is a standard two player miniature wargame with each player taking command of a company or battalion level force consisting of hand painted miniatures. There are also several scenarios in the book that allow the players to recreate some of the battles from the Team Yankee novel.

The game has an accompanying line of 15mm scale miniatures to use but it can be played with models from any manufacture.

The Game releases with 4 army lists that players may choose from, A United States tank Company, A United states Mechanized Infantry company, A Soviet Tank Battalion, and a Soviet Mechanized Infantry Battalion.

boardgame.name: Feats of Spellcasting II
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Aren’t there enough feats already?

Certainly it’s possible to make an extremely effective spellcaster without adding any of the feats in this book. However, rather than attempt to create must-have feats that patch rules in the game, or open entirely new ways to fill crucial party roles, this book is designed to just add some fun options. These are feats that give a spellcaster an interesting or defining quirk. These feats allow characters to pluck out their own eyes for magic sight, have power over spells they create (and name after themselves), and invoke magic items with words of power that frighten their enemies. They are designed to make spellcasters (and the games they appear in) interesting, unexpected, and memorable.

boardgame.name: CZFT Basic Rules
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Characters in CZFT have four Attributes: Strength, Constitution, Dexterity, and Intelligence. These Attributes are randomly generated by 1D10+8 each for humans. High Attribute Scores (14 and above) yield action bonuses. Characters have Skill Points derived from Intelligence and distributed into available Skills.

Most non-combat game rolls involve rolling 2D10 and attempting to "roll under" the relevant attribute (modifiers may apply). Hit Points are derived from Constitution. Combat takes place in rounds; each opponent can take one action in each round. Actions happen in initiative order. Combat rolls are made with D100 against the relevant combat Skill. Called shots are allowed but yield a penalty.

boardgame.name: De vogelvrijverklaarden van Tombstone
boardgame.description:
This cardgame plays a lot like "Werewolves of Miller's Hollow", but with a twist.

The settings is the wild west, in a town called Tombstone. Two outlaws and a wannabe outlaw are hidden amongst the cowboys, and each night they kill an innocent cowboy. Their goal is to bring down the number of cowboys untill they outnumber them. But each morning the cowboys gather and hang someone, hoping to eliminate the outlaws.

Each player is secretly assigned a role : you may be the sheriff, the barber, the doctor, the priest or the hero. You can hide this identity, but if you want to use your special ability (like healing a shot person if you are the doctor, of taking the confession of another player if you are the priest) then you need to reveal your card. Of course, this is a risk if the outlaws consider you dangerous.

Unlike the werewolves, the outlaws can have a special character too. The priest, or even the hero, can be an outlaw. This makes the paranoia even bigger: when the cowboys decide to hang a person, why does the judge decide to let him free? Why doesn't the doctor heal the priest after being shot? This make the game much more intriguing. No more "hey i'm a special character i'm innocent"...

Another difference is that you can play the game with lesser persons. There are rules to play the game with up to 25 players, but slightly different rules to make it playable with 13-24 players, 4-12 players, and even 2-3 players. In the case of 4-12 players each player has more than one character, which means you are not eliminated out of the game as soon as one character dies.

boardgame.description:
The Queen has called on her fearless knights to help unite the kingdom. In this cooperative game, players must build a safe path across the green fields of Dragonwood while dashing past diving dragons! Will you make it before you run out of resources? Or will the dragons be victorious?

In Dragon Dash, players take turns drawing tiles and placing paths to connect both sides of the board and randomly placing dragon tiles with the roll of the dice. Players must connect both sides of the board with one continuous path to win. If the dragons block the path so that it cannot connect, the game is lost. Along the way, players may collect knight's gear (shield, helmet and sword) which may be used to defeat dragons who may attempt to destroy their paths.

boardgame.name: Starfleet Legions
boardgame.description:
ENGLISH
Starfleet Legions is a card game for 1-4 players which takes us to a science fiction universe where humanity is threatened by the alien Insectoids: A highly hostile race intended to end our specie. You'll be in command of a infantry squad, traveling through the galaxy and eliminating the threat. Starfleet Legions is a competitive game. The squadron with the most Victory Points at the end of the game wins. You'll need get the most from your 4 soldiers, equip them with the best possible weapons and use cunning tactics.

During combats, each player will be drawing and allocating result cards for the members of their squads, trying to maximize casualties and considering their strengths and advantages. All the result decks have the same proportion of cards: critical success (1), success (2), partial success (3), partial failure (1), failure (2) and fumble (1). When a card is assigned to a soldier, it can no longer be changed during that round of combat. All results are evaluated at the end of the round depending on the skills and equipment of each soldier in the squad. Requiring enemies are eliminated before those who has survived attack the squad members.

ESPAÑOL:
Starfleet Legions (Las Legiones del Espacio), es un juego de cartas de 1 a 4 jugadores, que nos traslada a un universo de ciencia ficción en el que la Humanidad se encuentra amenazada por los Insectoides alienígenas: Una raza altamente hostil, que pretende acabar con nuestra especie. Estarás al mando de una Escuadra de infantería de Las Legiones del Espacio, encargada de viajar a lo largo de la galaxia, eliminando a la amenaza Insectoide allí donde se encuentre. Starfleet Legions es un juego competitivo, en el que la Escuadra con mayor cantidad de Puntos de Victoria resultará vencedora al final de la partida. Deberás sacar el máximo partido posible a tus cuatro Soldados, equiparlos con las mejores armas posibles y utilizar sus tácticas con astucia.

Durante los combates, cada jugador extrae y asigna cartas de resultado para los miembros de su escuadra, tratando de maximizar las bajas y teniendo en cuenta sus fortalezas y ventajas. Todos los mazos de resultados tienen la misma proporción: crítico (1), éxito (2), éxito parcial (3), fallo parcial (1), fallo (2) y pifia (1). Cuando se asigna una carta a un soldado, ya no se puede cambiar durante ese asalto de combate. Todos los resultados son evaluados al final de la ronda en función de las habilidades y equipo de cada soldado en la escuadra. Los enemigos que se requieran son eliminados antes de que, los que ha sobrevivido ataquen a los miembros de la escuadra.

boardgame.name: The Twelve Days of Onyx Condition Cards
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ho! Ho! Ho! We had so much fun creating the Overly Specific Condition Cards and a special [Condition Card for Halloween], we decided we wanted to try something new.

These Twelve Days of Onyx Condition Cards are holiday themed Conditions selected from contest entries submitted by members of our creative and awesome community. It was really, really difficult to choose our 12 favorites from so many awesome submissions, yet that was the task and here are the ones our Onyx Path team chose.

Part of the Chronicles of Darkness rules, Conditions add an additional layer of consequence and reward to certain actions in Chronicles of Darkness games. Various things within the course of a game can cause Conditions. These include exceptional successes, supernatural abilities, and really any situation where the Storyteller thinks they can be used to heighten the drama of a game.

boardgame.name: Vampires
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A vampire is a being from folklore who subsists by feeding on the life essence, typically blood, of living creatures. But what do they look like as a member of the undead, what was their life like, how do they feed?

All these aspects and more are covered in this volume of the CDG. The CDG (Creature Description Generator) range is designed with a fantasy setting in mind, but can easily be used for sci-fi or modern/horror settings.

Aspects covered by this Creature Description Generator:

Apparent previous life: What was the vampire in their previous life before they were turned into the undead?
Bane/Weakness: What causes the vampire harm or can weaken them so they can finally be killed? Not all vampires are repulsed by holy symbols.
Clothing: What is the state of their clothing? Is it in pristine condition? Related to their previous life?
Companions: Is the vampire on their own, or do they have followers and others looking after them?
Features: This aspect covers their eye colouration, skin and anything normally visible.
Feeding: How does the vampire feed once they have caught their prey? What do they feed on?
Home base: Where and what does the vampire call home?
Hunting: Before they feed a vampire need to catch its prey. *How does it do that? Where does it hunt? Does it only hunt at a certain time of the year?
Killing Blow: How do you kill off one of these beasts for good?
Main goal: What is the main goal of the vampire now that it is undead?
Movement: How does the vampire primarily move? Does it glide with an unearthly grace, or appear in the shadows?
Powers & Skills: What skills and powers has becoming the undead granted the vampire?
Prey: What does the vampire hunt and what do they refuse to hunt?
Turned: How long ago was the vampire turned into the undead? What was their sire like?
Quirks and Rare Features: What odd personality quirk or rare feature does the vampire possess?

boardgame.name: Psychomachia
boardgame.description:
Psychomachia is a strategic card game in which you collect and command the seven deadly sins and seven heavenly virtues.

Each turn, players throw tokens that determine the quantity of virtuous and sinful actions that they will be able to perform. With these actions, players can place cards on the table, move cards to heaven, earth and hell, and summon the powers of the virtues and sins on their table and in their hand.

The goal of Psychomachia is to be the first person to place all seven virtues in heaven or all seven sins in hell, using any permitted combination of the four types of cards found in the game: Sin\Virtue cards, Heavenly Virtue cards, Deadly Sin cards, and Fate wildcards. Along the way, you can use the special powers of the virtues and sins in your possession to complete your collection first, or prevent other players from completing theirs.

boardgame.description:
History of Civilizations is a card-driven civilization game for 3 to 8 players that depict the rise and fall of empires from 4000BCE to 1900CE. Each player leads his empires to Glory through conquest, trade, science, religion, wealth, culture and many other means. The player with most Glory at the end of the game is the winner.

History of Civilizations differs from most other civilization board games as each player controls several civilizations at once. The game is divided into 5 Ages and takes place on a map spanning the entire world. Each round, players will take turns playing cards from their hand to build cities and wonders, move units, adopt religions, gain powerful leaders, trade with other empires, produce new units and many other things. Each card also depicts an empire that can be started if the game has reached a certain age and an event. Events can be played to affect the game in many ways; everything from natural disasters, generals, spies, revolts, golden ages and usurpers is included in the game.

Each empire has an individual set of Glory conditions that define what that particular empire must achieve in order to earn Glory points (victory points). For example, the Mongols want to be the largest empire in the world and conquer other empires, whereas England wants to have the most colonies and the largest navy. At the end of each round, all empires in play gain Glory according to their empire card. If an empire is performing poorly, it can simply be discarded to free up that empire slot, allowing you to play another empire later. This way, new and more modern empires keep coming into play as the game progresses.

History of Civilizations has many small and simple parts that make up a complex and highly dynamical game, where no two games will play out the same way. Imagine western history without the Romans and Greeks. What if the Aztecs and Incas held out against the Spanish conquistadors? What would the world look like if you made all the decisions?

boardgame.name: Ta bouche
boardgame.description:
Ta bouche is a card game from 1 to 5 players.

Includes: 110 cards (50 'Thoughts' cards, 50 'Retort' cards, 10 scoring cards), 1 dice.

Each player draws a card. One of the players read out loud one of the Thoughts lines: the other players, each at their turn, must use one of their 'Retort' lines to snap back the silliest or funnniest retort.

The player who fails to do that, or gives the lamest retort (after a decision by the reader), is shouted out: "Ta bouche" and loses 1 point on the score track.

At the end of a round, the player with the most points loses the game.

This is the familial variation of the game "Taggle". It's different from the classical version in the sense that the thoughts lines are adapted for the youngest, while "Taggle" is more 'adult' and could not please all parents.

You’re a robotic bellboy in a gigantic, chaotic, mega-hotel.

The hotel you serve is built upon (and in) a massive asteroid hurtling through space. boardgame.name: Trapped Dead: Lockdown
boardgame.description:
A small American town is overrun by the living dead! You manage to enter the town just before the military locks it down and now you must slice and shoot your way through thousands of zombies in order complete your mission in this action-packed Hack & Slash RPG.

In Trapped Dead: Lockdown, you fight your way through an interactive horror story as one of five different characters: The marine, the butcher, the assassin, the marshal and the exorcist. Every class comes with their own custom storyline, as well as individual strengths and abilities – the assassin is an expert in firearms, the butcher slaughters his enemies in melee combat and the exorcist fries zombies with his spiritual abilities. Each of the characters features his own individual skill tree, where you can unlock new defensive abilities and attacking moves to aid you in combat.

In Trapped Dead: Lockdown, you’ll have to choose between wielding two weapons at the same time or equipping one powerful two-handed one. The huge number of weapons keeps the gameplay interesting by letting you experiment with new combinations all the time: Would you like to send a concussion shot with the pistol first, then grab your hammer for a double blow, or rely on the mystical powers of the magic cross to set the zombies on fire? Clubs, axes, knives, revolvers, tasers, rifles, shotguns, bows, grenades, spell books, etc. There are hundreds of different weapons with which to kill the living dead - you can even use vehicles to run them over!

While discovering the huge game world, you’ll encounter many different types of rotting enemies and menacing boss monsters whose different strategies and abilities will require you to think fast and hit hard if you want to live. The monsters thirst for blood and move in quickly from all sides, so make sure not to be surrounded! Friendly NPCs may ask you for help or fight alongside you, but in the end, there’s only one rule in this world: kill or be killed! Lucky for you, the multiplayer mode enables you to fight the hordes together with up to 3 friends!

Source: The Publisher Website.

Shuffle all cards in the support pool and players' hands. Starting with the active player, deal them in clockwise order back to players' hands.

BETTER TO GIVE…
Choose a player. Each other player places 1 card from their hand on top of the chosen player's deck in any order. Then, each player except the chosen one draws a card.

[monster victorious]
…THAN TO RECEIVE!
Each player draws a random card from the player's hand to their right and places it on their own discard pile.

boardgame.name: The North Sea Runesaga
Runen der Nordsee-Saga
Saga des Runes de la Mer du Nord
boardgame.description:
The North Sea Runesaga is an epic competition for 2-4 players to collect the most Runestones and earn the highly coveted title of Chieftain. Players will progress through each chapter of the North Sea saga (Shipwrights, Raiders and Explorers).

Each chapter offers 3 unique Runestones for players to collect. These are awarded to the first player to achieve a particular objective. Gaining these Runestones also awards players advantages in successive chapters. Each of these Runestones also have 1 or 2 inscriptions (Shield, Horn and Hammer). The first player to gain 3 inscriptions of 1 type collects an additional Runestone for their efforts.

Players also gain 2 Runestones for winning each chapter or 1 Runestone for coming a close second. However, Runestones collected this way do not award any in-game advantages or inscriptions.

Once all 3 chapters have been played, the player with the most Runestones is the overall winner and takes the title of Chieftain!
